{{multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=September 2011}} {{advert|date=September 2011}} }} {{Infobox university | name = Technical University of Crete | native_name = Πολυτεχνείο Κρήτης | latin_name = | image = Tuclogo small.png | motto = | established = 1977 | type = Public | endowment = | staff = 270 | faculty = | president = | provost = | principal = | rector = Evangelos Diamandopoulos | chancellor = | vice_chancellor = | dean = | head_label = | head = | students = 3443 | undergrad = 2897 | postgrad = 546 | doctoral = | city = [[Chania]] | state = | country = [[Greece]] | campus = Kounoupidiana Campus, 7 km east of the city of Chania | free_label = | free = | colors = | colours = | mascot = | nickname = TUC | affiliations = [[Conference of European Schools for Advanced Engineering Education and Research|CESAER]] | website = [http://www.tuc.gr www.tuc.gr] }} [[File:TUC library.jpg|thumb|The library of the university, [[Chania]].]] The '''Technical University of Crete''' ('''TUC'''; {{lang-el|Πολυτεχνείο Κρήτης}}, ''Polytechneio Kritis'') is a state university under the supervision of the [[Greek Ministry of Education]] and was founded in 1977 in [[Chania]], [[Crete]]. The first students were admitted in 1984. The purpose of the institution is to conduct research, to provide under-graduate and graduate educational programs in modern engineering fields as well as to develop links with the Greek industry. The Technical University of Crete ranks highly among the Greek technical universities in terms of research productivity, research funding, scientific publications and citation per faculty member.{{Cite news|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/universities/technical-university-crete |title=QS World University Rankings - Technical University of Crete |language=en |work=QS World University Rankings |date=2017-09-01 |access-date=}}{{Cite news|url=http://ceoworld.biz/2017/07/20/worlds-best-universities-for-oil-gas-and-petroleum-engineering-in-2017 |title=TUC among the World’s Best Universities For Oil, Gas, And Petroleum Engineering in 2017 |language=en |work=CEOWORLD magazine |date=2017-07-20 |access-date=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.tuc.gr/index.php?id=7 |title=Research Statistics - Technical University of Crete |publisher=TUC |language=el |accessdate=}} == Emblem == The emblem of the Technical University of Crete is [[Daedalus]]. == Academic structure == {{cleanup university|section|date=May 2010}} The Technical University of Crete comprises five Engineering Schools, all of which offer undergraduate and postgraduate study programmes. The School of Electronic and Computer Engineering was renamed to School of Electrical and Computer Engineering in July 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.tuc.gr/index.php?id=departments-en |title=Academic Schools - Technical University of Crete |publisher=TUC |language=en |accessdate=}}
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Schools ! Divisions |- ! School of [[Production engineering|Production Εngineering]] {{cite web|url=http://www.pem.tuc.gr/index.php?id=4890 |title=School of Production Engineering and Management |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} | * Production Systems * Decision Sciences * Management and Administration |- ! School of [[Mining engineering|Mineral Resources Engineering]] {{cite web|url=https://www.mred.tuc.gr/index.php?id=3341 |title=School of Mineral Resources Engineering |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} | * Exploration and Positioning * Mining Technology * Minerals Exploitation |- ! School of [[Electrical engineering|Electrical]] and [[Computer engineering|Computer]] Engineering {{cite web|url=http://www.ece.tuc.gr/index.php?id=4483 |title=School of Electrical and Computer Engineering |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} | * Electronics and Computer Architecture * Computer Science * Control Systems * Telecommunications |- ! School of [[Environmental engineering|Environmental Engineering]] {{cite web|url=http://www.enveng.tuc.gr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=179&Itemid=536&lang=en |title=School of Environmental Engineering |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} | * Environmental Management * Environmental Process Design and Analysis * Hydraulics and Geoenvironmental Engineering |- ! School of [[Architecture]] {{cite web|url=https://www.arch.tuc.gr/en/home/ |title=School of Architecture |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} | * Architectural Design * Urban Design and Planning * Digital Media in Architectural Design * Visual Arts |}
== Research == The Technical University of Crete is particularly active in conducting basic and applied research.{{cite web|url=https://www.tuc.gr/index.php?id=385 |title=Research – Technical University of Crete |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} * School of Production Engineering and Management {{cite web|url=http://www.pem.tuc.gr/index.php?id=5002 |title=Research – School of Production Engineering and Management |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} ''Laboratories:'' Computer Aided Manufacturing, Intelligent Technological Systems, Computer Aided Design, Robotics, Environmental Engineering and Management, Dynamic Systems and Simulation, Decision Support Systems, Data Analysis and Forecasting, Financial Engineering, Management Systems, Work Safety and Cognitive Ergonomics, Applied Socioeconomic Research. * School of Electrical and Computer Engineering {{cite web|url=http://www.ece.tuc.gr/index.php?id=4504 |title=Research – School of Electrical and Computer Engineering |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} ''Laboratories:'' Distributed Multimedia Information Systems and Applications, Intelligent Systems, Software Technology and Network Applications, Electronics, Electric Circuits and Renewable Energy Sources, Microprocessor and Hardware, Automation, Information and Networks, Telecommunications, Digital Image and Signal Processing. * School of Mineral Resources Engineering {{cite web|url=https://www.mred.tuc.gr/index.php?id=3344 |title=Research – School of Mineral Resources Engineering |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} ''Laboratories:'' Applied Geology, Applied Geophysics, Applied Mineralogy, Petrology and Economic Geology, Geodesy and Geomatics, Rock Mechanics, Mine Design, Solid Fuels Beneficiation and Technology, Ore Processing. * School of Environmental Engineering {{cite web|url=https://www.tuc.gr/index.php?id=385 |title=Research – School of Environmental Engineering |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} ''Research Fields:'' Liquid and Solid Waste Management, Water Resources and Coastal Engineering, Sustainable Energy, Remediation Engineering, Air Pollution, Environmental Sciences. * School of Architecture {{cite web|url=https://www.arch.tuc.gr/en/the-school/getting-acquainted-with-the-school/ |title=Research – School of Architecture |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} ''Research Fields:'' Architectural Design, Urban design and Planning, Digital Technologies in Architectural Design, History and Theory of Architecture and Art, Landscape Architecture, Visual Arts, Restoration of Buildings. == Campus == The campus is located on a panoramic site in the peninsula of Maelehas (ancient Keamon, also known as [[Akrotiri, Crete|Akrotiri]]) and covers an area of {{convert|750|acre|km2}}, 7 km Northeast of [[Chania]]. Library, IT & Communications Centre, cafeterias, sports facilities, and students' dormitories are located on campus.{{cite web|url=https://www.tuc.gr/index.php?id=387 |title=Campus - Technicall University of Crete |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} == Academic evaluation == The Technical University of Crete is among the top Greek institution with the highest rate of research publications per faculty member.{{cite web|url=https://www.tuc.gr/index.php?id=3338&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=14590&cHash=c3bc97597c9ac6d357ab8dece459cf12 |title=TUC ranked 151-200 in Civil Engineering subject at the ShanghaiRanking's Global Ranking of Academic Subjects - 2017 |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.tuc.gr/index.php?id=3338&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=14683&cHash=834b14c25b60008e33450f19d2a6c1d5 |title=TUC Professors broke the 10,000 citation level according to Google Scholar |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.tuc.gr/index.php?id=3338&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=14682&cHash=3c51915ee4f9fa1b2ec0da5cec50ed38 |title=TUC Professor in the top 1.5% of the Social Science Research Network according to the international ranking "SSRN Top Authors" |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.tuc.gr/index.php?id=awards-en |title=Awards & Distinctions - Technical University of Crete |publisher=TUC |accessdate=}} In 2015 the external evaluation of the institution cited Technical University of Crete as ''Worthy of merit''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.adip.gr/instevalreports/FINAL%20EXTERNAL%20EVALUATION%20REPORT_TECHNICAL%20UNIVERSITY%20OF%20CRETE.pdf |title=Technical University of Crete - External Evaluation Report|language=en |date=2015 |publisher=www.adip.gr}}"''Two members of the EEC give a lower evaluation (positive) due to the fact that QA of the Institution is actually not in place and also that the absence of a feasible strategic plan hampers the Institution’s operation and its readiness to change.''" An external evaluation of all academic departments in [[List of universities in Greece|Greek universities]] was recently conducted by the [[Hellenic Quality Assurance and Accreditation Agency]] (HQAA).[http://www.adip.gr/en/index.php Hellenic Quality Assurance and Accreditation Agency] * Department of Environmental Engineering (2011) [http://www.adip.gr/external/TUC_EnvEng_2011.pdf HQAA East Technical University, Turkey * {{flagicon|Denmark}} University Of Southern Denmark, Faculty of Enginering, Denmark ==Honorary Doctorate Degree Awards== The Technical University of Crete has conferred the title Doctor Honoris causa to the following distinguished scientists: * 5/5/1993. Rudolf Kalman, founder of the modern mathematical control theory, Emeritus Professor at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology. * 3/5/1996. Sir David Cox, founder of Modern Statistics, Professor at the University of Oxford. * 2/12/1996. Michael Athans, founder of the self-adjusting control in the field of automation, Professor at M.I.T. * 26/5/2000. Kenneth R. Laker, founder of micro-electronics in the field of active filters of acoustics surface waves, Professor at the University of Pennsylvania. * 10/6/2002. Bernard Roy, founder of the European School of Multicriteria Decision Analysis, Emeritus Professor at the Universite Paris-Dauphine. * 15/12/2004. Mohammad Jamshidi, expert on modelling, control and applications of Large-scale complex systems, Regents Professor at the University of New Mexico. * 15/12/2004. Athanasios Fokas, expert on non-linear mathematical science, Professor at the University of Cambridge. * 4/3/2005. [[Laurent Lafforgue]], outstanding contribution to Langlands program in the field of number theory and analysis, Permanent Professor at the Institute des hautes etudes scientifiques (IHES). * 1/2/2006. Eftychios Bitsakis, outstanding contribution to Theoretical Physics, Professor Emeritus at the University of Ioannina. == Memberships == The Technical University of Crete cooperate with universities and other organizations of higher learning and research. Within this framework, it has been a member of the European University Association since 1995 (E.U.A), a member of the Conference of European Engineering schools of Advanced Research (CESAER) since 2003. '''CESAER''', is a non-profit association of leading [[engineering]] [[university|universities]] in [[Europe]]. CESAER was set up on May 10, 1990, with headquarters in [[Leuven]], [[Belgium]]. The main objectives are to provide high quality engineering education in Europe and to improve links between association members in research, as well as postgraduate and continuing education. ==Members of CESAER== {| class="wikitable" !Country !Institution(s) |- |'''{{AUT}}''' |[[Vienna University of Technology]] |- |'''{{BEL}}''' |[[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]]

[[University of Southampton]] |} TUC is also a member of the Réseau Méditerranéen des Ecoles d'Ingénieurs (RMEI), a member of the Community of Mediterranean Universities (CMU) and a full partner of NEARCTIS (A Network of Excellence for Advanced Road Cooperative Traffic management in the Information Society). It is an academic network gathering the main teams working on the field of traffic management and optimisation, with a particular focus on cooperative systems for road traffic optimisation, but it covers a wide scope as it appears that cooperative systems have to be integrated into the whole traffic management systems. The full partners are: * {{flagicon|Netherlands}} [[Technische Universiteit Delft]], [[Netherlands]] * {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[Imperial College London]], United Kingdom * {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[University College London]], United Kingdom * {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[University of Southampton]], United Kingdom * {{flagicon|Switzerland}} [[EPFL]], [[Switzerland]] * {{flagicon|Greece}} Technical University of Crete, Greece * {{flagicon|France}}Institut National de Recherche sur les Transports et leur Securite, France * {{flagicon|France}}Europe Recherche Transport, France * {{flagicon|Germany}} [[German Aerospace Center|Deutsches Zentrum für Luft- und Raumfahrt e.V.]], Germany == Mobility programs== SOCRATES is a programme funded by the European Union that covers all areas and levels of education. The section involving higher education is called Erasmus. Students can participate in this exchange programme by studying at a particular university in another European country for a short period. Study placements involve either attending classes at a host university. The Technical University of Crete, has signed many bilateral agreements with other universities. The number of the outgoing and incoming students is increasing, year after year, indicating that the programme is very successful. ==See also== * [[List of universities in Greece]] * [[Polytechnic (Greece)]] * [[University of Crete]] * [[Open access in Greece]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.tuc.gr/5397.html Technical University of Crete (TUC) - {{No footnotes|date=April 2009}}
In 1978, 1979, and 1981 the [[MENC: The National Association for Music Education|Music Educators National Conference]] sponsored the '''Ann Arbor Symposium''' on the Applications of Psychology to the Teaching and Learning of Music at the [[University of Michigan]]. The University of Michigan and the [[Theodore Presser Foundation]] were co-sponsors. The purpose of the Symposium was to explore the relationship between research in certain areas of [[behavioral psychology]] and [[music education]].
==Sessions==
In Session I (1978), papers were presented by leading music education researchers to acquaint the participating [[psychologist]]s with music education practices, and to present issues to which research psychologists might contribute their knowledge and expertise.
Session II (1979) consisted of presentations of papers by the psychologists on the topics discussed by the music educators the year before. Each presentation in Session I was followed by a response from a psychologist, and in Session II by a music educator.
==Bibliography== * Mark, M.L. (1986). ''Contemporary Music Education.'' New York: Schirmer Books. * ''Documentary Report of the Ann Arbor Symposium: Applications of Psychology to the Teaching and Learning of Music.''(1981). Reston: Music Educators National Conference. * ''Documentary Report of the Ann Arbor Symposium Session III: Applications of Psychology to the Teaching and Learning of Music.''(1983). Reston: Music Educators National Conference.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ann Arbor Symposium}} [[Category:Music education organizations]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox library | library_name = The People's Library | name_en = | library_logo = | image = Peoples Library Occupy Wall Street 2011 Shankbone.JPG | caption = The People's Library in November 2011 | country = [[United States]] | type = | scope = | established = 2011 | ref_legal_mandate = | location = [[New York City]] | coordinates = | branch_of = | num_branches = | items_collected = | collection_size = 5,554 (2011) | criteria = | legal_deposit = | req_to_access = | annual_circulation = | pop_served = | members = | budget = | director = | num_employees = | website = | phone_num = | references = <ref name='ALA 2011-11-17' /> }}
'''The People's Library''', also known as '''Fort Patti'''<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-11-16' /><ref name='Zabriskie 2011-10-18' /> or the '''Occupy Wall Street Library''' ('''OWS Library'''), was a [[library]] founded in September 2011 by [[Occupy Wall Street]] protesters in lower [[Manhattan|Manhattan's]] [[Zuccotti Park]] located in the [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] of [[New York, NY|New York City]].<ref name='Diaz 2011-10-20'>{{cite news | first = Shelley | last = Diaz | title = Occupy Wall Street's Library Keeps Growing | date = October 20, 2011 | url = http://www.schoollibraryjournal.com/slj/home/892496-312/occupy_wall_streets_library_keeps.html.csp | work = School Library Journal | accessdate = November 21, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63LjJOTpi?url=http://www.schoollibraryjournal.com/slj/home/892496-312/occupy_wall_streets_library_keeps.html.csp | archivedate = November 21, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> It was temporarily evicted when Zuccotti Park was cleared on November 15, 2011, during which time 5,554 books were thrown away by the [[New York City Police Department]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Occupy Wall Street Library Reportedly Thrown Away By NYPD [UPDATE]|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/15/occupy-wall-street-library_n_1094941.html|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=6 May 2014}}</ref><ref name='SLJ 2011-11-18'>{{cite news | title = ALA Condemns Seizure of Occupy Wall Street People's Library | date = November 18, 2011 | url = http://www.schoollibraryjournal.com/slj/home/892857-312/ala_condemns_seizure_of_occupy.html.csp | work = School Library Journal | accessdate = November 20, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63LZkTgyf?url=http://www.schoollibraryjournal.com/slj/home/892857-312/ala_condemns_seizure_of_occupy.html.csp | archivedate = November 20, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> In April 2013, the [[Government of New York City]] was ordered to pay $366,700 for the raid, which was found to have violated the protesters' [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First]], [[Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourth]] and [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth]] Amendment rights.<ref name="Raw Story">{{cite web|title=Court orders NYPD to pay $360,000 for raid that destroyed Occupy Wall Street library|url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2013/04/10/court-orders-nypd-to-pay-360000-for-raid-that-destroyed-occupy-wall-street-library/|work=Raw Story|accessdate=6 May 2014}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Day 9 Occupy Wall Street September 25 2011 Shankbone 34.JPG|thumb|Library beginnings]] [[File:Day_9_Occupy_Wall_Street_September_25_2011_Shankbone_40.JPG|thumb|The People's Library, September 25, 2011 (day 9)]] Founded shortly after Occupy Wall Street activists began protesting, the People's Library began with a cardboard box full of books which was left at [[Zuccotti Park]] by a [[library science]] student from [[New York University]].<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-10-18'>{{cite news | first = Christian | last = Zabriskie | title = A Library Occupies the Heart of the Occupy Movement | date = October 18, 2011 | url = http://americanlibrariesmagazine.org/news/10182011/library-occupies-heart-occupy-movement | work = American Libraries Magazine | accessdate = November 20, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63Kj0ifup?url=http://americanlibrariesmagazine.org/news/10182011/library-occupies-heart-occupy-movement | archivedate = November 20, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref name='Nader 2011-09-29'>{{cite news | first = Alexia | last = Nader | title = The Occupy Wall Street Library | date = September 29, 2011 | url = http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/books/2011/09/the-occupy-wall-street-library.html | work = The New Yorker | accessdate = November 21, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63LiPpYc0?url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/books/2011/09/the-occupy-wall-street-library.html | archivedate = November 21, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref name='Pous 2011-10-10'>{{cite news | first = Terri | last = Pous | title = Occupy Wall Street: Their Own Mini-Government, Complete With Library | date = October 10, 2011 | url = http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/10/10/occupy-wall-street-their-own-mini-government-complete-with-library/ | work = Time | accessdate = November 21, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63LlPzTiG?url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/10/10/occupy-wall-street-their-own-mini-government-complete-with-library/ | archivedate = November 21, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> A weather event then resulted in the loss of the collection, which prompted [[Betsy Fagin]] to bring the idea of an official library before the movement's General Assembly a few weeks later.<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-10-18' /> The assembly appointed Fagin as [[librarian]] and a second collection was started.<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-10-18' /> As time passed, volunteers received additional books and resources from readers, private citizens, authors and corporations.<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-11-16'>{{cite news | first = Christian | last = Zabriskie | title = The Occupy Wall Street Library Regrows in Manhattan | date = November 16, 2011 | url = http://americanlibrariesmagazine.org/news/11162011/occupy-wall-street-library-regrows-manhattan | work = American Libraries | accessdate = November 19, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63J3Pw49t?url=http://americanlibrariesmagazine.org/news/11162011/occupy-wall-street-library-regrows-manhattan | archivedate = November 19, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> In one such instance, musician [[Patti Smith]] contributed a tent to the library, which was named ''Fort Patti'' in her honor and used as the library's primary structure until it was destroyed in November.<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-11-16' /><ref name='Zabriskie 2011-10-18' /> On October 13, 2011 Brookfield Properties, which owns Zuccotti Park, the location of the OWS encampment, ordered a clearing of the park under the pretext of "cleaning". Working groups within OWS were divided over how to respond, however, a decision was made for people to stay, but for infrastructure and possessions to be moved to safety. Between one and two thousand books were moved overnight to a large artist warehouse in [[Jersey City]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://macaulay.cuny.edu/eportfolios/adiv14_magazine/2014/05/19/zuccotti-park-and-occupy-wall-street/|title=Zuccotti Park and Occupy Wall Street|last=|first=|date=2014|website=|publisher=|access-date=March 26, 2017}}</ref> Brookfield Properties eventually conceded to public pressures and did not move forward with the proposed cleaning. The books where then returned to the park.The library has on occasion received volunteer assistance from the [[Homelessness in the United States#New York City|local homeless population]], according to a librarian from the [[New York Public Library]].<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-10-18' />
==Collection== The library had 9,500 books cataloged in [[LibraryThing]] as of November 2012, and its collection was described as including some rare or unique articles of historical interest that originated as a result of the Occupy protests.<ref name='ALA 2011-11-17'>{{cite press release | url = http://ala.org/ala/newspresscenter/news/pr.cfm?id=8568 | title = ALA alarmed at seizure of Occupy Wall Street library, loss of irreplaceable material | accessdate = November 19, 2011 | date = November 17, 2011 | publisher = [[American Library Association]] | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63J2BDwBW?url=http://ala.org/ala/newspresscenter/news/pr.cfm?id=8568 | archivedate = November 19, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> According to ''[[American Libraries]]'', the library's collection had "thousands of circulating volumes," which included "holy books of every faith, books reflecting the entire political spectrum, and works for all ages on a huge range of topics."<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-11-16' /> A librarian was quoted as saying that "donated books are never rejected, even if they seem at odds with the ideology behind the protest."<ref name='King 2011-10-24'>{{cite news | first = Ritchie | last = King | title = For Quiet Moments Between Protests, a Growing Library | date = October 24, 2011 | url = http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/24/for-quiet-moments-between-protests-a-growing-library/ | work = The New York Times | accessdate = November 20, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63KqK9nez?url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/24/for-quiet-moments-between-protests-a-growing-library/ | archivedate = November 20, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> The collection development policy of the Library, or lack thereof, is this: "It only has two points: everything we have was donated to us, and we accept everything," thus, "not only was the Library for the people, but, as they are responsible for its creation, that it is of the people."<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Norton|first=Daniel|last2=Henk|first2=Mandy|last3=Fagin|first3=Betsy|last4=Taylor|first4=Jaime|last5=Loeb|first5=Zachary|year=2012|title=Occupy Wall Street librarians speak out|url=|journal=Progressive Librarian|volume=38/39|pages=3–16|via=}}</ref> The Library Working Group of the OWS People's Library worked in a consensus leadership structure, meaning they need at least a 90% agreement among members to make a decision happen. However, the degreed librarians could make many autonomous actions if they did not detrimentally affect the library or its mission.<ref name=":0" /> Unique articles include the ''Occupy Wall Street Poetry Anthology'', which was compiled by the library based on its live poetry sessions and featured poets such as [[Adrienne Rich]] and [[Anne Waldman]] "alongside high school kids."<ref name='Greenberg 2011-11-08'>{{cite news | first = Emily | last = Greenberg | title = A Truly Public Library | date = November 8, 2011 | url = http://www.cornellsun.com/section/arts/content/2011/11/08/truly-public-library | work = The Cornell Daily Sun | accessdate = November 20, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63KvvKL6j?url=http://www.cornellsun.com/section/arts/content/2011/11/08/truly-public-library | archivedate = November 20, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref name='Tharoor 2011-10-25'>{{cite news | first = Ishaan | last = Tharoor | title = From Chomsky to the Onion: What's on the Shelves at Occupy Wall Street's Library | date = October 25, 2011 | url = http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/10/25/from-chomsky-to-the-onion-whats-on-the-shelves-at-occupy-wall-streets-library/ | work = Time | accessdate = November 21, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63LkTSXCw?url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/10/25/from-chomsky-to-the-onion-whats-on-the-shelves-at-occupy-wall-streets-library/ | archivedate = November 21, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
===Zuccotti Park eviction=== [[File:Egan Nottage Lethem OWS 2011 Shankbone.JPG|thumb|Writers [[Jennifer Egan]], [[Lynn Nottage]] and [[Jonathan Lethem]] giving a reading at the library on November 7, 2011]] During the early morning of November 15, 2011, [[New York City|city]] workers from the [[New York Police Department|Police Department]] and [[New York City Department of Sanitation|Sanitation Department]] forcibly evicted everyone in the park at that time and loaded their [[personal property|property]] and the 5,500+ book collection into garbage trucks, after a decision by [[Government of New York City|city officials]] and park owners [[Brookfield Office Properties]] using "[[public health]] and [[environmental issue]]s" as justification.<ref name='ALA 2011-11-17' /> The People's Library facility was among the assets seized.<ref name='Witt 2011-11-18'>{{cite news | first = Emily | last = Witt | title = American Library Association Condemns Destruction of OWS People's Library | date = November 18, 2011 | url = http://www.observer.com/2011/11/american-library-association-condemns-destruction-of-ows-peoples-library/ | work = The New York Observer | accessdate = November 19, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63J1esFlO?url=http://www.observer.com/2011/11/american-library-association-condemns-destruction-of-ows-peoples-library/ | archivedate = November 19, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Following the police action, observers reportedly saw the library's books being thrown into dumpsters.<ref name='ALA 2011-11-17' />
New York City mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]] stated that the library's collection was safely stored at the sanitation garage on [[57th Street (Manhattan)|57th Street]], and that it could be retrieved on the following Wednesday.<ref name='Howard 2011-11-16'>{{cite news | first = Greg | last = Howard | title = OWS Library: Thousands of Books Missing, Destroyed | date = November 16, 2011 | url = http://slatest.slate.com/posts/2011/11/16/ows_library_reports_missing_books_property_.html | work = Slate | accessdate = November 19, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63J4JQsWw?url=http://slatest.slate.com/posts/2011/11/16/ows_library_reports_missing_books_property_.html | archivedate = November 19, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> After library representatives returned from the sanitation garage on Wednesday, they posted on the library's website that most of its collection and equipment had been destroyed, damaged or lost. Among the missing or damaged property was the [[tent]] that housed the library (including its necessary [[infrastructure]]), [[laptop]]s and [[rubber stamp]]s bearing [[Seal (device)|marks]] used to identify library resources.<ref name='Witt 2011-11-18' /><ref name='Howard 2011-11-16' /> In all, library representatives reported recovering 26 [[box]]es of books from the city.<ref name='Attenberg 2011-11-17'>{{cite news | first = Jami | last = Attenberg | title = How I helped rescue the OWS library | date = November 17, 2011 | url = http://www.salon.com/2011/11/17/saving_ows_library/singleton/ | work = Salon | accessdate = November 19, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63J7AawJ7?url=http://www.salon.com/2011/11/17/saving_ows_library/singleton/ | archivedate = November 19, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> A final total of books recovered that were still usable and actually originated with the library was 802, a small fraction of the number seized.<ref>Norton, D., Henk, M., Fagin, B., Taylor, J., & Loeb, Z. (2012). Occupy Wall Street librarians speak out. ''Progressive Librarian, 38/39'', 3-16. Retrieved from ebscohost.com</ref>
===Reaction=== The [[American Library Association]] (ALA) issued a statement that the dissolution of the library was "unacceptable" because libraries "serve as the cornerstone of our democracy and must be safeguarded." The ALA added that the "very existence of the People's Library demonstrates that libraries are an organic part of all communities" and that libraries "serve the needs of community members and preserve the record of community history." Of concern was the loss of some rare historical documents and records, which it said are endemic to the Occupy movement.<ref name='ALA 2011-11-17' /> Some of the library's [[reference work|reference materials]] and some of its regular books lost were autographed by their authors, either while visiting the library or through courier to express moral support.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} One such example included ''[[What Work Is]]'', which was signed and donated in person by [[United States Poet Laureate]] [[Philip Levine (poet)|Philip Levine]] hours before its destruction when the park was cleared.<ref name='Palmer 2011-11-23'>{{cite news | first = Gianna | last = Palmer | title = NYPD raid destroyed thousands of books, Occupy says | date = November 23, 2011 | publisher = [[The Kansas City Star]] | url = http://www.kansascity.com/2011/11/23/3283335/nypd-raid-destroyed-thousands.html | work = McClatchy Newspapers | accessdate = November 24, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63R449iwy?url=http://www.kansascity.com/2011/11/23/3283335/nypd-raid-destroyed-thousands.html | archivedate = November 24, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
The executive director of [[Common Cause]] said in a statement that the [[Government of New York City|City]] should "replace each title, buying two new copies for each one destroyed" and "for whatever number is unaccounted for, the city should provide Occupy's librarians with funds sufficient to buy twice as many."<ref name='SLJ 2011-11-18' /><ref name='CC 2011-11-17'>{{cite press release | url = http://www.commoncause.org/site/apps/nlnet/content2.aspx?c=dkLNK1MQIwG&b=4773613&ct=11515683 | title = Mayor Bloomberg should replace books lost in Zucotti Park police raid | accessdate = November 20, 2011 | date = November 17, 2011 | publisher = [[Common Cause]] | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63LZyCsbt?url=http://www.commoncause.org/site/apps/nlnet/content2.aspx?c=dkLNK1MQIwG&b=4773613&ct=11515683 | archivedate = November 20, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> [[University of California, Irvine|UC Irvine]] history professor [[Mark LeVine]] expressed his sentiment that "tents can be replaced, even most personal effects. But destroying books is like destroying the soul of the movement" and filmmaker [[Udi Aloni]] added that "When they disrespect books, they disrespect humankind, and when they destroy books, they destroy the spirit of humanity. The library was great because people gave more than they took. OWS was not just a place for activism, but also a place for education and rethinking; not for just blathering on when you don't know, but being humble and willing to learn. By taking out the library, they've tried to stop that crucial process."<ref name='LeVine 2011-11-17'>{{cite news | first = Mark | last = LeVine | title = The People's Library and the future of OWS | date = November 17, 2011 | url = http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2011/11/2011111681642279467.html | work = Al Jazeera | accessdate = November 19, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63JEusc69?url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2011/11/2011111681642279467.html | archivedate = November 19, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
Editors at ''[[2600: The Hacker Quarterly]]'' mourned the loss of the library's donated electronics and computer equipment, which they believed to have been destroyed by a blunt object.<ref name='2600 2011-11-18'>{{cite news | title = Donated Laptops for "Occupy Wall Street" Destroyed in NYPD Action | date = November 18, 2011 | url = http://www.2600.com/news/view/article/12159 | work = 2600: The Hacker Quarterly | accessdate = November 20, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63KFfsDSx?url=http://www.2600.com/news/view/article/12159 | archivedate = November 20, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
===Restoration=== [[File:St James Park Library Yurt.jpg|A library formed by [[Occupy Toronto]] activists was located in a traditional [[Mongols|Mongolian]] [[Yurt]] at [[Cathedral Church of St. James (Toronto)|St. James Park]] in Canada|thumb|right]] Efforts to restore the library were initiated shortly after its seizure.<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-11-16' /> The library started a third collection with 100 replacement books, which were subsequently surrounded by police and confiscated by sanitation workers on the night of November 16, 2011.<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-11-16' /><ref name='LeVine 2011-11-17' /><ref name='Greenberg 2011-11-18'>{{cite news | first = Michael | last = Greenberg | title = Occupy Wall Street Turns a Corner | date = November 18, 2011 | url = http://www.nybooks.com/blogs/nyrblog/2011/nov/18/crackdown-zuccotti-occupy-wall-street/ | work = The New York Review of Books | accessdate = November 19, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63JOHqwfw?url=http://www.nybooks.com/blogs/nyrblog/2011/nov/18/crackdown-zuccotti-occupy-wall-street/ | archivedate = November 19, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> A fourth collection was formed on November 17, 2011 and is currently being distributed from mobile carts.<ref name='SLJ 2011-11-18'/>
==Services== The library used an [[honor system]] to manage returns and originally operated [[24/7]].<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-10-18' /><ref name='Tharoor 2011-10-25' /> It offered weekly poetry readings on Friday nights, provided a reference service that was frequently staffed by professional librarians, and could attempt to procure materials not held by the People's Library.<ref name='ALA 2011-11-17' /><ref name='Zabriskie 2011-10-18' /><ref name='Nader 2011-09-29' /><ref name='NYDN 2011-10-17'>{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pUFn8kKDwuk | title = Voices from Zuccotti: Steve Syrek, 33 | accessdate = November 20, 2011 | work = The New York Daily News | publisher = [[YouTube]] | quote = I've even got one guy who wants to help us procure any materials we want from the interlibrary loan system, which means we are a legitimate, fully functioning research library. Someone could come here and request an article of any kind and we could theoretically get it for free and give it to them.}}</ref> The library's cataloging system is accessible online at [[LibraryThing]], which donated a free lifetime membership.<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-10-18' /> Prior to the Zuccotti park raid, a lighted reading room, public laptop computers and a [[Wi-Fi]] [[wireless network|network]] were also offered.<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-11-16' /><ref name='Zabriskie 2011-10-18' />
==Court case== On May 24, 2012, the librarians, represented by [[Norman Siegel]], sued the city, mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]], police commissioner [[Raymond Kelly]], and sanitation commissioner John Doherty in federal court.<ref>https://librarianshipwreck.wordpress.com/2014/04/16/librarian-is-my-occupation-a-history-of-the-peoples-library-of-occupy-wall-street/</ref><ref>http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/869140874</ref> On April 9, 2013, a New York city court ordered the city to pay $366,700 for the raid in which police destroyed some 5,000 books that were part of the library.<ref name="Raw Story"/>
==Sister libraries== Since the formation of the library, activists at related protests throughout North America and in Europe have formed several sister libraries.<ref name='Zabriskie 2011-10-18' /><ref name='Fister 2011-10-27'>{{cite news | first = Barbara | last = Fister | title = Why the Occupy Wall Street Movement Has Libraries | date = October 27, 2011 | url = http://www.libraryjournal.com/lj/home/892578-264/why_the_occupy_wall_street.html.csp | work = Library Journal | accessdate = November 20, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63KgMq1H4?url=http://www.libraryjournal.com/lj/home/892578-264/why_the_occupy_wall_street.html.csp | archivedate = November 20, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref name='Saltzman 2011-11-02'>{{cite news | first = Rebecca | last = Saltzman | title = From Spectator to Participant: How the Last Week Changed My Relationship With Occupy Oakland | date = November 2, 2011 | url = http://www.beyondchron.org/news/index.php?itemid=9654 | work = BeyondChron | accessdate = November 20, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/63KexS6FL?url=http://www.beyondchron.org/news/index.php?itemid=9654 | archivedate = November 20, 2011 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{overly detailed|date=April 2018}} {{third-party|date=April 2018}} {{advert|date=January 2017}} }}
'''UDOO''' is a [[single-board computer]] with an integrated [[Arduino]] Due compatible [[microcontroller]], designed for computer science education, the world of [[Maker movement |Makers]] and the [[Internet of Things]].
The product was launched on [[Kickstarter]] in April 2013, reaching wide consensus. "The product line involves three single board computers – UDOO QUAD/DUAL (2013), UDOO NEO (2015), UDOO X86 (2016) – that differ over various aspects, plus the UDOO BLU and the set of UDOO BRICKS."<ref>[https://www.udoo.org/discover/ UDOO Product Line]</ref>
UDOO is a development platform that merges a Dual or Quad Core [[ARM architecture|ARM]] [[Freescale]] [[Cortex-A9]] [[i.MX]] 6 CPU, that can run [[Linux]] or [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[operating system|operating systems]], and an Arduino Due compatible board with a dedicated ARM [[Atmel]] [[SAM3X]]8E CPU.
UDOO is a joint effort of Aidilab srl and SECO USA Inc, in collaboration with a multidisciplinary team of researchers with expertise in [[interaction design]], [[embedded systems]], [[sensor networks]] and [[cognitive science]].
== History == ;Kickstarter campaign The UDOO project was launched on Kickstarter on April 9, 2013 by AidiLab — a Siena University startup — and SECO - an embedded computing firm - and reached the goal of $27,000 in about 40 hours.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/udoo/udoo-android-linux-arduino-in-a-tiny-single-board/posts/450961|title=Update 2: 27k goal! · UDOO: Android Linux Arduino in a tiny single-board computer|publisher=|access-date=12 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tech.fanpage.it/udoo-il-micro-pc-italiano-che-rivoluziona-la-prototipazione-raggiunge-il-goal-su-kickstarter-in-40-ore/|title=UDOO, il micro-pc italiano che rivoluziona la prototipazione raggiunge il goal su Kickstarter in 40 ore|publisher=|access-date=12 July 2016}}</ref> The goal was well exceeded as 4,172 backers pledged $641,614.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/udoo/udoo-android-linux-arduino-in-a-tiny-single-board/|title=UDOO: Android Linux Arduino in a tiny single-board computer|publisher=|access-date=12 July 2016}}</ref>
== Hardware == The UDOO board is equipped with two CPUs. The Freescale i.MX 6 is an ARM Cortex A9 processor based on ARM v7 instruction set. Next generation graphics and high-definition video are central in the i.MX 6 series. The i.MX 6 series supports up to 1080p60 video playback, enabling exceptional high-quality videos with low power consumption for devices playing high-definition content. The 3D graphics engine in the top of the line i.MX 6 Quad and i.MX 6 Dual processors are capable of providing up to 200 Mt/s, which enables ultra-vivid, realistic graphics critical for multimedia. These applications combine the power of the main cores with the until-now-untapped potential of the 3D engine to perform computational tasks.
Otherwise Atmel SAM3X implements [[real-time computing]] and allows full compatibility with Arduino Due prototyping board. With this solution UDOO can be used like an Arduino Due microcontroller and programmed in the same way.
They are both stand-alone with different clocks and no shared memory. They both process their tasks asynchronously without any kind of emulation.
They do however share some communication channels: * a UART Serial (used with Linux) * a USB OTG Bus (used with Android) * all the digital pins of the external Arduino pinout.
=== Processors === The i.MX 6 Dual/6 Quad application processors are the latest additions of Freescale Semiconductor to a growing family of multimedia-focused products offering high performance processing optimized for lowest power consumption. The i.MX 6 Dual/6 Quad processors feature Freescale's advanced implementation of the ARM Cortex-A9 core, which can be interfaced with DDR3-1066, LV-DDR3-1066 and LPDDR2-1066 (single and dual channel) DRAM memory devices.
====Freescale i.MX 6==== The i.MX 6<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freescale.com/webapp/sps/site/prod_summary.jsp?code=i.MX6Q|title=i.MX6Q-i.MX 6Quad Processors-Quad Core-NXP|publisher=|access-date=12 July 2016}}</ref> Dual/6 Quad Processor is based on the ARM Cortex A9 MPCore Platform, which has the following features:
* ARM Cortex A9 MPCore Dual or Quad core CPU configurations (with TrustZone) * Symmetric CPU configuration where each CPU includes: ** 32 Kbyte L1 Instruction Cache ** 32 Kbyte L1 Data Cache ** Private Timer and Watchdog ** Cortex-A9 NEON MPE (Media Processing Engine) Co-processor. The ARM Cortex A9 MPCore complex includes: * General Interrupt Controller (GIC) with 128 interrupt support * Global Timer * Snoop Control Unit (SCU) * 1 Megabyte unified L2 cache shared by all CPU cores (Dual or Quad) * Two Master AXI (64-bit) bus interfaces output of L2 cache * NEON MPE coprocessor
The i.MX 6 Quad processor makes use of dedicated Hardware accelerators in order to meet the targeted multimedia performance. The use of HW accelerators is a key factor inobtaining high performance at low power consumption numbers, while keeping the CPU core relatively free to perform other tasks.
The i.MX 6 Quad processor incorporates the following hardware accelerators:
* VPU Video Processing Unit * Two IPUv3H — Image Processing Unit (version 3H) * GPU3Dv4 — 3D/2D Graphics Processing Unit (OpenGL ES 2.0), version 4 * GPU2Dv2 — 2D Graphics Processing Unit (BitBlt). * GPU VG — OpenVG 1.1 Graphics Processing Unit * ASRC — Asynchronous Sample Rate Converter
Miscellaneous IPs and interfaces: * Three SSI that support I2S/AC97, up to 1.4 Mbit/s each * Enhanced Serial Audio Interface (ESAI), up to 1.4 Mbit/s each channel * Five UART, up to 4.0 Mbit/s each * RS232 interface * 9-bit RS485 multidrop mode * One of the five supports 8-wire (uart1) while the other four support 4-wire. * Five eCSPI (Enhanced CSPI). * Three I2C, supports 400 kbit/s * Gigabit Ethernet Controller (IEEE1588 compliant), 1Gbit/s/10/100 Mbit/s * Four Pulse Width Modulators (PWM) * System JTAG Controller (SJC) * GPIO with interrupt capabilities * 8x8 Key Pad Port (KPP) * Sony Philips Digital Interface (SPDIF), Rx and Tx * Two Controller Area Network (FlexCAN), 1 Mbit/s each * Two Watchdog timers (WDOG) * Audio MUX (AUDMUX)
;Atmel SAM3X Atmel’s SAM3X/A series is a member of a family of Flash microcontrollers based on the high performance 32-bit ARM Cortex-M3 RISC processor. It operates at a maximum speed of 84 MHz and features up to 512 Kbytes of Flash and up to 100 Kbytes of SRAM. The peripheral set includes a High Speed USB Host and Device port with embedded transceiver, an Ethernet MAC, 2x CANs, a High Speed MCI for SDIO/SD/MMC, an External Bus Interface with NAND Flash controller, 5x UARTs, 2x TWIs, 4x SPIs, as well as 1 PWM timer, 9x general-purpose 32- bit timers, an RTC, a 12-bit ADC and a 12-bit DAC. The SAM3X/A series is ready for capacitive touch thanks to the QTouch library, offering an easyway to implement buttons, wheels and sliders. The SAM3X/A architecture is specifically designed to sustain high speed data transfers. It includes a multi-layer bus matrix as well as multiple SRAM banks, PDC and DMA channels that enable it to run tasks in parallel and maximize data throughput. It operates from 1.62V to 3.6V and is available in 100- and 144-pin QFP and LFBGA packages. The SAM3X/A devices are particularly well suited for networking applications: industrial and home/building automation, gateways.
;Processor connectivity The Freescale i.MX 6 and the Atmel SAM3X are connected through a UART Serial Port embedded on the board. It works exactly like an Arduino connected to an external computer with a USB cable. The SAM3X and Linux communicate on a two way channel, exchanging messages with a tested baudrate of 115200.
This serial connection is also accessible from the external pins 0 and 1 of the Arduino compatible pinout. The SAM3X programming port is accessible in the same way as Arduino Due: via a USB-to-serial converter or directly on the external pinout. The serial UART is connected to the iMX 6 pins KEYROW0 and KEYCOL0. On the SAM3X side it is connected to pins URXD and UTXD. The shared serial is also available through the micro-USB plug CN6. By removing the J18 jumper, you can communicate on the same channel, which now becomes shared.
;Memory UDOO uses 4 Micron MT41J256M16RE-15E RAM modules (2Gbit for each module) for a total of 1GByte. The clock frequency is 400mhz for UDOO Dual and 528mhz for UDOO Quad.
The memory system consists of the following levels:
* Level 1 Cache - 32KB Instruction, 32KB Data cache per each core. * Level 2 Cache - Unified instruction and data (1MByte) * On-Chip Memory * Boot ROM, including HAB (96 KB) * Internal multimedia / shared, fast access RAM (256KByte) * Secure/non-secure RAM (16 KB)
=== Networking === ;Ethernet The MAC-NET core, in conjunction with a 10/100/1000 MAC, implements layer 3 network acceleration functions. These functions are designed to accelerate the processing of various common networking protocols, such as IP, TCP, UDP, and ICMP, providing wire speed services to client applications. UDOO uses KSZ9031RNX Ethernet transceiver. It is a completely integrated triple-speed (10BASE-T/100BASE-TX/1000BASE-T) Ethernet physical layer transceiver for transmission and reception of data on standard CAT-5 unshielded twisted pair (UTP) cable. The KSZ9031RNX provides the Reduced Gigabit Media Independent Interface (RGMII) for direct connection to RGMII MACs in Gigabit Ethernet processors and switches for data transfer at 10/100/1000 Mbit/s. The KSZ9031RNX reduces board costs and simplifies board layout by using on-chip termination resistors for the four differential pairs and by integrating an LDO controller to drive a low-cost MOSFET to supply the 1.2V core.
;Wi-Fi Module GWF-3M08 is a WLAN module supporting IEEE 802. 11 b/g/n standards with 6-pin connector supporting USB 2.0 /1.1 interface. This is a small form factor and low cost compact WLAN module designed for the wireless connectivity of products with embedded system. This module operates in 2.4 GHz ISM frequency band, it applies a highly integrated MAC/BBP and RF single chip RT5370 with 150Mbit/s PHY rate supporting. This module can be built-in other embedded applications such as IP Camera, IP set top box, GPS, Internet radio apparatus, it can be directly soldered on a main PCB.
Features: * 802.11b: 1, 2, 5.5, 11Mbit/s; 802.11g: 6, 9, 12, 24, 36, 48, 54Mbit/s * 802.11n: (20 MHz) MCS0-7, Support up to 72Mbit/s (40 MHz) MCS0-7, support up to 150Mbit/s * OFDM, Peak rate 150Mbit/s, Peak throughput 90Mbit/s. * Security support for 64/128 WEP, WPA, WPA2, TKIP, AES * Operates in 2.4 GHz frequency bands. Power Management * WPS and TX external control, WiFi direct supported
=== Peripherials and connectors === Front connectors and ports: * Speakers jack 3.5mm * Mic jack 3.5mm * USB 2.0 Host x2 type A * 10/100/Gigabit Ethernet RJ-45 connector * HDMI connector * USB Client microUSBconnector * i.MX 6 / SAM3X serial microUSB connector * RESET button * WAKE-UP button
Up-side connectors and ports: * CSI Camera port * [[Serial ATA#eSATA|eSATA]] port (UDOO quad only) * LVDS connector * Power-on LED * Alternative DC-IN connector * SAM3X SPI pins * USB WiFi module connector * Extra USB 2.0 Host port * Real Time Clock External Battery (3 Volts) * SD Reader * SAM3X JTAG header
=== Multimedia === ;GPU Summary of features in the GPU3D includes: * OpenGL ES 2.0 compliance, including extensions; OpenGL ES 1.1; OpenVG 1.1 * IEEE 32-bit floating-point pipeline * Ultra-threaded, unified vertex and fragment shaders * Low bandwidth at both high and low data rates * Low CPU loading * Up to 12 programmable elements per vertex * Dependent texture operation with high-performance * Alpha blending * Depth and stencil compare * Support for 8 fragment shader simultaneous textures * Support for 4 vertex shader simultaneous textures * Point sampling, bi-linear sampling, tri-linear filtering, and cubic textures * Resolve and fast clear * 8k x 8k texture size and 8k x 8k rendering target * GPU2D has the following features: * Bit BLT & stretch BLT * Rectangle fill and clear * Line drawing * High performance stretch and shrink * Mono expansion for text rendering * ROP2, ROP3, and ROP4 * Alpha blending including Java 2 Porter-Duff compositing blending rules * Support rendering size of 32Kx32K * 90/180/270 degree rotation * Transparency by monochrome mask, chroma key, or pattern mask * Color space conversion between YUV and RGB * High quality image scaling, using up to 9x9 separable filter
;LVDS panels UDOO provides one of the two i.MX 6 LVDS outputs to the external pinout. This input is used to communicate RGB data and controls to external LCD displays with LVDS interface, or through LVDS receivers.
The LVDS port may be used as one single-channel output.
;USB OTG - Android Accessory Mode When you boot Android, the OTG BUS is switched to connect to the SAM3X; therefore, the connection is between the two processors. If you plug a USB cable to CN3 it doesn’t work since it is disconnected.
With this setup, the i.MX 6 can communicate with the SAM3X using the Android ADK protocol. To do this you must program the SAM3X with a sketch which includes specific libraries and installs an app on Android configured to use the ADK protocol.
=== Specifications === ====Summary====
UDOO is based on a Dual or Quad core ARM cortex-A9 CPU delivering great performance on both [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[Linux]] OS, and a dedicated [[ARM architecture|ARM]] processor for the GPIO. The specifications <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.udoo.org/features/|title=Linux-Android-Arduino Development Board with ARM CPU - UDOO|publisher=|access-date=12 July 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160530024920/http://www.udoo.org/features/|archivedate=30 May 2016|df=}}</ref> are: * Freescale i.MX 6 ARM Cortex-A9 CPU Dual/Quad core at 1 GHz * Integrated GPU: each processor provides three separate accelerators for 2D, OpenGL® ES2.0 3D and OpenVG * Atmel SAM3X8E ARM Cortex-M3 CPU (same as Arduino Due) * RAM DDR3 1GB * 76 fully available GPIO * Arduino-compatible R3 1.0 pinout * HDMI and LVDS + Touch (7<nowiki>''</nowiki> and 15<nowiki>''</nowiki>) * Ethernet RJ45 (10/100/1000 MBit) * WiFi module * Micro USB and Micro USB OTG * USB type A (x2) plus a supplementary USB key and a supplementary USB connector (requires a specific wire) * I/O analog audio * SATA (Quad-Core version only) * CSI Camera connection * Micro SD (boot device) * 6V to 18v power supply and external battery connector
=== Accessories === The available accessories<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shop.udoo.org/usa/accessories.html?___from_store=eu&popup=no|title=Accessories - Shop – Udoo|publisher=|access-date=12 July 2016}}</ref> are:
* MIPI 5 MP Camera module * MIPI 5 MP IR Camera module * Kit LCD 7<nowiki>"</nowiki> Touch * Kit LCD 15.6<nowiki>"</nowiki> Touch * Kit LCD 15.6<nowiki>"</nowiki> * Starter Kit (Cables Kit + Power Supply + Micro SD) * Cables Kit * Power Supply
== Software == The Udoo board comes with two micro SD card (optional) with Android and Ubuntu Linux installed. {{Empty section|date=September 2013}}
== Development == {{Empty section|date=September 2013}}
== Applications == {{Empty section|date=September 2013}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Vladimir Alekseyevich Betz | image = Vladimir Betz.JPG | image_size = 200px | caption = | birth_date = 26 April 1834 | birth_place = [[Tatarovshina]] near [[Oster]], [[Chernigov Governorate|Chernigovskaya guberniya]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = 12 October 1894 | death_place = [[Kiev]], Russian Empire<ref>Jessie Dobson: ''Anatomical Eponyms. Being a Biographical Dictionary of those Anatomists whose Names have become Incorporated into Anatomical Nomenclature, with Definitions of the Structures to which their Names have been Attached and References to the Works in which they are Described''. E. & S. Edinburgh/London: Livingstone, 1962, p. 24.</ref> | residence = [[Ukraine]], Russian Empire | citizenship = Russian Empire | nationality = | field = [[Anatomy]] | work_institution = [[Kiev University]] | alma_mater = [[Kiev University]] | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | known_for = discovery of [[Betz cells]] | author_abbreviation_bot = | author_abbreviation_zoo = | prizes = medals for brain tissue samples at All-Russian Manufacturing Exhibition (1870), [[Weltausstellung 1873 Wien|Vienna World Exposition (1873)]] | religion = | footnotes = }} [[File:Betz monument.jpg|thumb|upright|Vladimir Betz headstone at the [[Vydubychi Monastery]], [[Kiev]]. The inscription reads: "''To the initiator of studies of the [[Central Nervous System]], the professor of anatomy of the [[Kiev University]], Vladimir Alekseyevich Betz. 1834-1894. Grateful [[Morphology (biology)|morphologists]] of [[Ukraine]].''"]] '''Vladimir Alekseyevich Betz''' ({{lang-ua|Володи́мир Олексійович Бец}}) ({{OldStyleDate|26 April|1834|14 April}} – {{OldStyleDate|12 October|1894|30 September}})<ref>Kushchayev, Sergiy V., et al. "The Discovery of the Pyramidal Neurons: Vladimir Betz and a New Era of Neuroscience." JOURNAL OF NEUROSURGERY. Vol. 113. No. 2. 5550 MEADOWBROOK DRIVE, ROLLING MEADOWS, IL 60008 USA: AMER ASSOC NEUROLOGICAL SURGEONS, 2010.</ref> was a Ukrainian anatomist and histologist, professor of the [[Kiev University]] (Bogomolets National Medical University), famous for the discovery of [[Betz cell|giant pyramidal neurons]] of [[primary motor cortex]].
Vladimir Betz began his education in the [[Nizhyn]] [[Gymnasium (school)|Gymnasium]] (Ukraine, part of the Russian Empire at that time). Later he transferred to the 2nd [[Kiev]] Gymnasium and graduated from it in 1853. In 1860 he received a physician's diploma from the Medicine faculty of [[Saint Vladimir University]] in Kiev (now [[Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv]]) and was appointed a [[prosector]]'s aide at the [[anatomy]] department. He went abroad to study in May 1861 and returned in September 1862, having studied with and attended the lectures of professors Brücke, Bunsen, Kölliker, Helmholtz, Kirchhoff. From 1864 to 1867 he lectures anatomy and histology at the university, rising in 1868 to the rank of Extraordinary Professor and in 1870 becoming Ordinary Professor of the anatomy department.
Brain tissue preparations made by Betz were awarded medals twice - at the All-Russian manufacturing exhibition in 1870 and at [[Vienna World Exposition]] of 1873. In 1874, Vladimir Alekseyevich described the giant pyramidal neurons in the primary motor cortex, which later were named ''[[Betz cell]]s''.<!--
--><ref name="Betz_1874">Betz W. (1874) ''Anatomischer Nachweis zweier Gehirncentra.'' Centralblatt für die medizinischen Wissenschaften. 12:578-580, 595-599.</ref><!--
-->
Betz' most prominent works include: * "On the hepatic blood circulation" (1863) * "A new method of human [[Central nervous system|CNS]] exploration" (1870) * "On the grouping of the convolutions of human brain" (1871) * "Two centers in the human brain cortex" (1875) * "An anatomy of the human brain surface, with an atlas and 86 tables" (1883) * "Historical figures of the Russian South-West" (1883, coauthored by prof. B.A.Antonovich)
== References == {{reflist|2}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Betz, Vladimir Alekseyevich}} [[Category:1834 births]] [[Category:1894 deaths]] [[Category:People from Oster]] [[Category:Russian anatomists]] [[Category:Histologists]] [[Category:Russian neuroscientists]] [[Category:Ukrainian neuroscientists]] [[Category:Russian academics]] [[Category:Ukrainian academics]] [[Category:Ukrainian medical writers]] [[Category:Imperial Russian inventors]] [[Category:Ukrainian inventors]] [[Category:Medical educators]] [[Category:Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv alumni]] [[Category:Imperial Russian biologists]] [[Category:Ukrainian biologists]] [[Category:Ukrainian medical researchers]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Wilfrid Derome |image = |image_size = 100px |birth_date = 19 April 1877 |death_date = 24 November 1931 |residence = [[Canada]] |nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] |field = [[Forensic scientist]] |work_institution = Laboratoire des Sciences Judiciaires et de Médecine Légale |known_for = Founder of first [[Forensic science]] laboratory in North America |prizes = French Hall of Fame of Criminalistic |footnotes = }} '''Wilfrid Derome''' (19 April 1877 – 24 November 1931) was a [[Quebec]] [[forensic scientist]] known as the founder of the first [[Forensic science]] laboratory in North America, founded in [[Montreal]], Quebec, Canada.<ref>Beaudoin, F. Wilfrid Derome, terreur de la classe criminelle, Journal de la Criminalistique, 1(3), 2011, pp 98-100</ref> The laboratory is now called the Laboratoire des Sciences Judiciaires et de Médecine Légale.
==Biography== Dr. Derome was born in Napierville, Canada and studied at the [[College of Montreal]], Sainte-Marie College, and Joliette Seminary, where he received the Bachelor of Arts in 1898. Later, he received a doctorate of medicine from [[Université de Montréal|Université Laval in Montreal]] in 1902, interning at Notre Dame Hospital.
During 1908-1909, Dr. Derome studied Legal Medicine at the [[University of Paris]].<ref>Côté, J. Wilfrid Derome, expert en homicides, Boréal, Montreal, Quebec, Canada, 2003</ref>
During his career, he acted as associate editor the American Journal of Police Science, contributing two articles during 1930. He was a member of the [[International Association for Identification]] and the Société de médecine légale de France.
==Work== In 1910, Dr. Derome was appointed Professor of Legal Medicine and Toxicology at the University of Montreal and became head of the Laboratory of Notre Dame Hospital.
He founded, in June 1914, the first governmental [[Forensic science]] laboratory in North America in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. He acted as the Director of the lab since his death in 1931 at the age of 54.<ref>Beaudoin, F. Wilfrid Derome, terreur de la classe criminelle, Journal de la Criminalistique, 1(3), 2011, pp 98-100</ref> He testified as Medical Expert and Ballistic Expert to the Crown in many legal cases during his career.
In 1922, he became the first Expert in North America to testify in front of the Court on the determination of ethyl alcohol in the blood. In 1926, Dr. Derome invented the microspherometer which can reveal the marks left on the surface of bullets fired from a firearm for the purpose of identification. This discovery allowed to present scientific evidence in Court for the first time in ballistics.<ref>Beaudoin, F. Wilfrid Derome, terreur de la classe criminelle, Journal de la Criminalistique, 1(3), 2011, pp 98-100</ref>
In 1929, the Derome laboratory was visited by [[J. Edgar Hoover]], from the [[FBI]], in order to plan the foundation of the FBI laboratory.
==Awards==
* 2001 – Quebec Government named the building that housed the Forensic science Laboratory and the headquarters of the [[Sûreté du Québec]] by his name: Building Wilfrid Derome * 2011 - French Hall of Fame of Criminalistic (Association Québécoise de Criminalistique, Canada)
==Books== * Derome, W. Précis de médecine légale, Cie d'imprimerie des Marchands, Montreal, Quebec, Canada, 1920 * Derome, W. Lieu du crime, 1928 * Derome, W. Expertises en armes à feu, Impr. alliés syndicats cathol.-nationaux, Montreal, Quebec, Canada, 1929
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources==
*American Journal of Police Science, 1931.
==External links== *[http://www.securitepublique.gouv.qc.ca/lsjml/a-propos/historique-laboratoire.html Laboratoire des Sciences Judiciaires et de Médecine Légale site] (in French)
{{Authority control}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox Person | name = Winifred Lamb | image = Winifred_Lamb_(1894-1963).jpg | image_size = | caption = <!--fair use picture only--> | birth_name = | birth_date = 3 November, 1894 | birth_place = [[Campden Hill]] | death_date = 16 September, 1963 | death_place = [[Easebourne]] | death_cause = | residence = | other_names = | known_for = Honorary Keeper of Greek Antiquities | education = Newnham College | employer = FitzWilliam Museum | occupation = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = | nationality = [[United Kingdom]] }} '''Winifred Lamb''' (1894-1963) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[art historian]], [[archeologist]], and museum curator who specialised in [[Ancient Greece|Greek]], [[Ancient Rome|Roman]], [[Anatolia]]n cultures and artifacts. The bulk of her career was spent as the Honorary Keeper of Greek Antiquities at the [[University of Cambridge]]'s [[Fitzwilliam Museum]] from 1920 - 1958.<ref>[http://www.fitzmuseum.cam.ac.uk/gallery/cockerell/pigstytopalace/antiquities.html Fitzwilliam Museum Antiquities]</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Classics in 19th and 20th Century Cambridge: Curriculum, Culture and Community|last=Gill|first=David W.J.|publisher=Cambridge Philological Society|year=1998|isbn=0-906014-23-9|editor-last=Stray|editor-first=Christopher|location=Cambridge|pages=135-156|chapter=Winifred Lamb and the Fitzwilliam Museum}}</ref> She was the first woman archaeologist involved in the British Anatolian excavations,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://arthistorians.info/lambw|title=Lamb, Winifred|last=|first=|date=2018-02-21|work=Dictionary of Art Historians|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en}}</ref> and the Fitzwilliam museum states that she was a "generous benefactor and raising the profile of the collections through groundbreaking research, acquisitions and publications."<ref>[http://www.fitzmuseum.cam.ac.uk/gallery/cockerell/pigstytopalace/antiquities.html Fitzwilliam Museum Antiquities]</ref>
==Life== Lamb was born on 3 November 1894 at Holly Lodge, Campden Hill, London. She was the daughter of [[Edmund Lamb]], a former [[Member of Parliament]], and Mabel Lamb.<ref name=":1">{{Citation|title=Lamb, Winifred (1894–1963), archaeologist and museum curator {{!}} Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|url=https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/67872|work=The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|publisher=Oxford University Press|language=en|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/67872|access-date=2018-09-25}}</ref> Winifred Lamb attended [[Newnham College]] of [[Cambridge University]], studying [[Classics]], and earning her degree in 1917. She joined the British Naval Intelligence Department and served throughout [[World War I]], probably working on the decipherment of coded messages sent to German submarines.<ref name=":0" /> It was here that Lamb met [[John Beazley]], a renowned archaeologist also working in British Intelligence, who encouraged her in her research.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://arthistorians.info/lambw|title=Lamb, Winifred|last=|first=|date=2018-02-21|work=Dictionary of Art Historians|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en}}</ref> Her fieldwork and excavation skills were honed at the [[British School at Athens]], which she began attending in 1920.<ref>David W. J. Gill. Anatolian Studies. Vol. 50, (2000)[https://www.jstor.org/pss/3643010 Preview]</ref> In the same year, Lamb was appointed as the first Honorary Keeper of Greek and Roman Antiquities at the [[Fitzwilliam Museum]] in [[Cambridge]]; her work there involved arranging new displays and sorting and cataloguing the collections and new acquisitions, as well as enhancing the collections by donating numerous items herself (especially bronzes and pottery) and encouraging others to do so.<ref name=":0" /> Key publications from her work at the Fitzwilliam include a book on Greek and Roman bronze statues<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/Ancient_Greek_and_Roman_Bronzes.html?id=Ghi4AAAAIAAJ&redir_esc=y|title=Ancient Greek and Roman Bronzes|last=Lamb|first=Winifred|date=1929|publisher=Argonaut|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref> and two volumes of the ''[[Corpus vasorum antiquorum]]'' (corpus of ancient vases).<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=XPMMuQEACAAJ&dq=winifred+lamb&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiu36THytbdAhWFsaQKHblUAyEQ6AEIOTAD|title=Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain. Cambridge--Fitzwilliam Museum|last=Lamb|first=Winifred|date=1930|publisher=University Press|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ZkLMswEACAAJ&dq=winifred+lamb&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiu36THytbdAhWFsaQKHblUAyEQ6AEINDAC|title=Corpvs Vasorvm Antiquorvm: Cambridge 2, Fitzwilliam Museum|last=Lamb|first=Winifred|date=1936|language=en}}</ref>
Lamb took part in excavations in [[Mycenae]], [[Sparta]], and [[Macedonia (ancient kingdom)|Macedonia]]. Following her work in Macedonia, Lamb had started to consider the link between the southern Balkans, the northern Aegean, and northwest Anatolia; her search led her to [[Lesbos]], where in 1928 she identified the site of [[Thermi]]. She led her own excavation on this site from 1929 - 1933, publishing her results as a book in 1936.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OolxBAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=winifred+lamb&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi_rtnKy9bdAhVGEVAKHYLoABEQ6AEILjAB#v=onepage&q=winifred%20lamb&f=false|title=Excavations at Thermi in Lesbos|last=Lamb|first=Winifred|date=2014-10-02|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781107433106|language=en}}</ref> She visited the archaeological excavation of Troy in 1930 and 1932, which inspired further work, allowing her to associate Thermi towns IV and V with Troy IIa. She gave a lecture, expanding on these views, as part of the 1936 exhibition at the [[Royal Academy of Arts]] on British Archaeological Discoveries in Greece and Crete 1886 - 1936.<ref name=gill110>David W. J. Gill, ''A Rich and Promising Site'': Winifred Lamb (1894 - 1963), Kusura and Anatolian archaeology'' in ''Anatolian Studies'', Vol 50 (2000) pp1-10</ref>
After this, she turned her attention to Ankara where, despite the problems for women working in Turkey at this time, other women archaeologists, including [[Gertrude Bell]], [[Margaret Hardie]], and [[Dorothy Lamb]] had excavated before the war.<ref name=gill110/> She excavated at [[Kusura, Sandıklı|Kusura]] in 1936 and 1937, and gave a lecture to the [[Society of Antiquaries of London|Society of Antiquaries]] in London on recent developments in the pre-history of Anatolia in 1937. Her interest in the area eventually helped establish the [[British Institute at Ankara|British Institute of Archaeology at Ankara]], of which she served as honorary secretary from 1948 - 1957.<ref>Getzel M. Cohen, Martha Sharp Joukowsky. Breaking Ground: Pioneering Women Archaeologists. University of Michigan 2004.</ref> She also published the Anatolian material held by the Fitzwilliam Museum.<ref name=":0" />
Lamb felt that more excavation was required in Anatolia, but her work was interrupted by the outbreak of World War II. In 1941 she joined the Greek language service of the BBC, and from 1942 to 1946 worked for the Turkish section of the Near Eastern department of the BBC. Towards the end of the war she was seriously injured when a V2 rocket hit her lodgings in north London, killing her housemates.{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}} She continued her work for the Fitzwilliam Museum until 1958, when she resigned in order to focus on her work on Anatolia and her involvement with the [[British Institute at Ankara|British Institute of Archaeology at Ankara]]; her donations and her collecting of items over this period had greatly enhanced the Museum's collections of classical antiquities.<ref name=":0" /> She died seven years after her retirement to Borden Wood on 16 September 1963 in Easebourne.<ref name=":1" />
She is the author of numerous books on Greek and Roman antiquities, including the 1929 publication ''Greek and Roman Bronzes'', which was standard reading for studies on the subject.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://arthistorians.info/lambw|title=Lamb, Winifred|last=|first=|date=2018-02-21|work=Dictionary of Art Historians|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en}}</ref> She also wrote a number of reviews for the [[Journal of Hellenic Studies]].
== Selected publications ==
* ''Greek and Roman Bronzes'' (Argonaut, 1929) * ''Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain. Cambridge -- Fitzwilliam Museum'' I & II (Oxford University Press, 1930 & 1936) * ''[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OolxBAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=winifred+lamb&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi_rtnKy9bdAhVGEVAKHYLoABEQ6AEILjAB#v=onepage&q=winifred%20lamb&f=false Excavations at Thermi in Lesbos]'' (Cambridge University Press, 1936)
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{merge to|Foundation for Environmental Education|discuss=Talk:Foundation for Environmental Education#Proposed merge with Young Reporters for the Environment|date=January 2018}} {{primarysources|date=April 2012}} <!-- linked from redirect [[Yre]] --> '''Young Reporters for the Environment''' is a programme of the [[Foundation for Environmental Education]]. An international network of youth in more than 25 countries, it promotes solutions to today’s environmental issues through [[investigative journalism]].
At the national{{where|date=May 2013}} level, participants choose local environmental issues to investigate, with the goal of communicating relevant information and solutions to the general public. The students carry out real journalistic enquiries and report their findings in the form of an article, photograph/[[Photo-essay|photographic essay]] or video.
An international competition is also held annually.<ref>[http://www.fee-international.org/en/Menu/Programmes/YRE What is YRE?]</ref>
== Links ==
The Foundation for Environmental Education is a [[non-governmental organisation|non-governmental]], [[non-profit organisation]] promoting [[sustainable development]] through environmental education, and is active in five programmes; [[Blue Flag beach|Blue Flag]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blueflag.global/ |title=Blue Flag |website=Blueflag.global |accessdate=October 28, 2016}}</ref> [[Eco-Schools]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ecoschools.global/ |title=Eco-Schools |website=ecoschools.global |accessdate=October 28, 2016}}</ref> [[Learning about Forests]] (LEAF),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leaf.global/ |title=Learning about Forests |website=Leaf.global |accessdate=October 28, 2016}}</ref> [[Green Key International]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greenkey.global/ |title=Green Key |website=Greenkey.global |accessdate=October 28, 2016}}</ref> and Eco-Schools. It has members in 76 countries worldwide.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.yre.global/ Young Reporters for the Environment (YRE)]
[[Category:International educational organizations]] [[Category:Youth organizations based in Denmark]] [[Category:International journalism organizations]] [[Category:International organizations based in Denmark]]
